Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To settle down and establish a new life in a new place.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To make a home and live permanently.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to Hakka migration and their adaptability in new lands.
First Example Sentence: 客家人落地生根，無論去邊都會開枝散葉。
Second Example Sentence: 阿明去馬來西亞落地生根，開咗餐館。
Third Example Sentence: 落地生根係客家精神个象徵。

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To accept the consequences of one’s own actions.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must bear the results of your choices.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from southern Chinese fishing communities; adopted by Hakka speakers.
First Example Sentence: 你愛去賭，就要食鹹魚抵渴。
Second Example Sentence: 做咗壞事，食鹹魚抵渴啦！
Third Example Sentence: 講白話無用，食鹹魚抵渴。

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Complex clause; subject-predicate with idiomatic object
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Money can make even the impossible possible.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Money has great power to influence outcomes.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across Han dialects; Hakka use emphasizes practical wisdom.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Hakka Chine: [jau˧ tsʰien˧ si˩ tet˧ kui˥ tʰui˧ mo˧]
First Example Sentence: 有錢使得鬼推磨，講真嘅。
Second Example Sentence: 佢靠有錢使得鬼推磨，攞到批文。
Third Example Sentence: 世界無咩過唔去，有錢使得鬼推磨。

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Two people constantly arguing without resolution.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from the image of chickens pecking each other endlessly.
Second Example Sentence: 同事之間雞啄唔斷，真煩。
Third Example Sentence: 兄弟兩人雞啄唔斷，阿媽喊頭大。

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Conflict between equally bad or selfish parties.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional rural metaphor used in satire.
First Example Sentence: 政客之間狗咬狗骨，百姓睇戲。
Second Example Sentence: 市場競爭激烈，好似狗咬狗骨。
Third Example Sentence: 兩幫人狗咬狗骨，無人有好處。

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: It’s hard to understand a person’s true intentions.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You can’t easily judge people’s hearts.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Shared Confucian saying emphasizing moral awareness.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Rumors always have some basis in truth.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: There’s usually a reason behind rumors.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common proverb throughout Chinese dialects, rooted in agrarian metaphor.
First Example Sentence: 無風不起浪，肯定有啲事發生。
Second Example Sentence: 佢話冇事？無風不起浪啊。
Third Example Sentence: 村裡傳言多，無風不起浪。

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Success comes naturally when conditions are right.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Things will succeed when the time is right.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Classical Chinese metaphor symbolizing patience and preparation.
Third Example Sentence: 學習要有耐心，水到渠成。

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone aims for something far beyond their reach.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from folk speech mocking over-ambition.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Hakka Chine: [khun˧ kau˧ sjɔŋ˩ sit˧ tʰin˥ ngo˩ njuk˧]
First Example Sentence: 阿強睏狗想食天鹅肉，笑死人。
Second Example Sentence: 講真，你係睏狗想食天鹅肉。
Third Example Sentence: 人人都知佢睏狗想食天鹅肉。

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To say one thing but do another.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Contemporary idiom used widely in modern discourse.
First Example Sentence: 佢講一套做一套，無人信佢。
Second Example Sentence: 政客最鍾意講一套做一套。
